chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a child or young person for depression?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Healthcare professionals involved in the assessment of a child (aged 5–11 years) or young person (aged 12–18 years) with depression should be aware of the general principles of care for children and young people with depression.

  • Take a history and record findings accurately in the notes. Consider offering the child or young person a consultation alone (without their family or carers).
    • Ascertain the length of time for which depressive symptoms have been present.
    • Identify risk factors for depression, such as personal or family history of depression or other mental health disorder, recent negative life events (for example parental divorce or seperation, or bereavement), family discord, physical or sexual abuse, or bullying.
    • Look for signs of self-neglect (for example unkempt appearance) or self-harm. See the CKS topic on Self-harm for more information.
    • Ask about the following key symptoms of depression:
      • Persistent sadness or low mood (or irritability).
      • Loss of interest or loss of pleasure (anhedonia).
      • Reduced energy leading to increased fatiguability and diminished activity.
    • If any key symptoms are present, ask about the following associated symptoms:
      • Reduced concentration and attention.
      • Reduced self-esteem and self-confidence.
      • Ideas of guilt and unworthiness.
      • Bleak and pessimistic views of the future.
      • Ideas or acts of self-harm or suicide.
      • Disturbed sleep.
      • Diminished appetite.
    • Enquire about other symptoms experienced, including headaches, stomach ache, and musculoskeletal pain.
    • Rule out other conditions that can cause symptoms of depression, such as anaemia (iron deficiency, B12, or folate), hypothyroidism, and viral infections (including infectious mononucleosis).  
    • Assess for comorbid conditions (such as anxiety) and for developmental, social, and educational problems. See the CKS topic on Generalized anxiety disorder for more information.
    • Ask about coping strategies used by the child or young person and/or their family/carers. These may be positive (such as helplines and peer, social, and family support groups) or negative (such as alcohol or drugs).
  • Be aware that in children and young people:
    • Depression can have a more insidious onset than in adults, may be characterized by irritability more than sadness, and often occurs concurrently with other behavioural disorders.
    • The clinical characteristics of depression vary according to age at presentation:
      • Children have a higher rate of physical complaints than adolescents, including headaches and abdominal pains, and tend not to look depressed.
      • Adolescents are more likely than children to complain of subjective feelings of low mood and to have a higher rate of suicidal thoughts and self-blame.
      • Adolescents tend to have more mood swings because of hormonal changes associated with this developmental stage of life. It is important to distinguish between normal highs and lows of mood and behaviors and moods and behaviors that are representative of depression.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based largely on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines Depression in children and young people: identification and management [National Collaborating Centre for Mental Health, 2005] and Depression in children and young people: identification and management [NICE, 2019] and on expert opinion in review articles [Haefner, 2016; BMJ, 2018].

  • According to NICE [National Collaborating Centre for Mental Health, 2005]:
    • Depression rarely occurs as a single psychiatric disorder. Concurrent symptoms of anxiety and behavioural disturbances are present in almost all cases, and between 50–80% of people with depression will also meet criteria for another non-depressive disorder.
    • Conduct disorder and/or oppositional disorder occur in around 25% of young people with depression, with a similar proportion meeting criteria for separation anxiety disorder. Around 15% will meet criteria for obsessive-compulsive disorder, and a further 5% will have an eating disorder, other anxiety states, or attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
  • NICE based the symptoms of depression on the World Health Organization (WHO) ICD-10 Classification of Mental and Behavioural Disorders [WHO, 1992].
